Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 46370 
Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
February 2013 
 
 
 
Republic of the Union of Myanmar: Developing the 
Asset Management Program for Myanmar Roads 
(Financed by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 15 January 2013) 
Currency unit  –  kyat (MK) 
MK1.00  =  $0.0011 
$1.00  =  MK857.77 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  MOC  –  Ministry of Construction 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Capacity development technical assistance (CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsector)  –  Transport, and information and communication technology (road 
transport) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting economic efficiency and enabling 
business  environment),  governance  (economic  and  financial 
governance), capacity development (institutional development) 
Location (impact)  –  National (high), rural (medium), urban (medium) 
Partnership  –  Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  K. Senga, Southeast Asia Department (SERD) 
Director  J. Lynch, Transport and Communications Division, SERD 
   
Team leader  J. Leather, Principal Transport Specialist, SERD 
Team members  M. Buendia, Senior Safeguard Specialist, SERD 
  N. Farrofo, Senior Project Officer, SERD 
  K. Leung, Finance Specialist, SERD 
  P. Rhee, Counsel, Office of the General Counsel 
  E. Thomas, Social Development Specialist, SERD 
  F. Villanueva, Senior Operations Assistant, SERD 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The proposed capacity development technical assistance (TA) to the Government of 
Myanmar will help the Ministry of Construction (MOC)1 develop an asset management and 
capacity development program to meet an immediate need to maintain  the country’s road 
assets,2 particularly on core primary and secondary networks. During a reconnaissance mission 
to Nay Pyi Taw, Myanmar 23–25 October 2012, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) discussed 
road  asset  management  issues  with  government  officials.  Agreement was  reached  on the 
impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and 
terms of reference of the TA. Details are in the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1).3 
 
2.  The TA will support ADB’s interim country partnership strategy for Myanmar for 2012–
2014, which made transport a priority sector for ADB assistance and highlighted the need for 
improved access and connectivity.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Transport will be a key part in the fundamental political, economic, and social change 
that Myanmar is poised to undergo. 
 
4.  Based on the country's size, population, and potential, Myanmar’s transport sector is 
significantly less developed than those of its neighbors in the Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations.  Average  road  density  across  all  association  member  countries  totals  about  11 
kilometers (km) per 1,000 people. Myanmar has only about 2 km for every 1,000 people, and 
much of this road is in poor condition. This makes the improvement of domestic connectivity by 
providing more efficient transport links between rural areas, markets, and urban centers a 
development priority. 
 
5.  Myanmar currently lacks the institutional and technical capacity to plan and carry out the 
required reform and development of the transport system. The transport sector has no overall 
strategy. Its institutional structure is fragmented, its management practices are centralized, and 
its investment and asset maintenance programs are poorly conceived. Plans at the subsector 
level  are  simple  lists  of  construction  and  maintenance  projects  with  limited  attention  to 
prioritization or evaluation. Subsector plans are not coordinated with either one another or the 
country’s overall development plan, which includes only a broadly expressed intention to extend 
transport links to all parts of the country to support national integration. 
 
6.  Investment in the transport sector since the 1990s has mainly come from government 
funds and tended to focus on major highways and railways. Comparatively little spending has 
gone  into  the  operation  and  maintenance  of  the  existing  transport  network.  Chronic 
underinvestment, notably in the secondary and tertiary road network, has left large parts of the 
country without adequate or reliable transport connections and with poor access to markets and 
                                                
1  MOC is responsible for less than 20% of Myanmar’s road network but these roads carry most of the country’s long-
distance heavy traffic. By concentrating on MOC and its part of the network, the TA will provide maximum early 
economic and social returns and be implemented in a relatively simple institutional environment where it can 
benefit from a well-skilled management team. 
2  These assets comprise all MOC-owned assets within a road corridor, including the road’s pavement, drainage 
structures, and such road furniture as signage and lighting, traffic control, and warning devices. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 13 February 2013. 
4  ADB. 2012. Interim Country Partnership Strategy: Myanmar, 2012–2014. Manila.

2   
essential services. This has severely constrained economic growth and social development in 
the more remote and border regions of Myanmar. 
 
7.  Expansion of the road system (particularly the secondary and tertiary networks) is clearly 
important for the country’s economic development, but the more immediate critical need is to 
maintain the existing core roads so that they accommodate the rapid increase in traffic that an 
expected acceleration in economic activity that is expected to result from new broad economic 
reforms. The TA will help address the conditions created by longstanding underinvestment in 
the management and maintenance of the part of the country’s road assets that are managed by 
MOC.  It  will  upgrade  the  ministry’s  operational  efficiency  through  capacity  development 
programs. This will improve transport connectivity and service reliability on important stretches 
of Myanmar’s road system, which in turn will stimulate inclusive economic growth. ADB will 
ensure that implementation includes collaboration between the TA and parallel ADB activities, 
including two TA projects: (i) Capacity Development and Institutional Support, and (ii) Capacity 
Building Support for Project Identification, both of which focus on transport in Myanmar.5 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The impact will be improved national connectivity through road transport infrastructure 
improvements.  The  outcome  will  be  the  development  of  a  road  maintenance  and  asset 
management prioritization program for the part of the national road network that is the MOC’s 
responsibility. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  The  TA  will  help  MOC  and  its  Public  Works  department  to  (i)  develop  a  road 
maintenance, asset management, and investment prioritization program for the part of the 
country’s road network that is under MOC; and (ii) develop and implement a related capacity 
development program for MOC and Public Works staff. Outputs will include (i) a comprehensive 
inventory of road assets in a management database and information system; (ii) a mechanism 
for prioritization of road maintenance, together with an investment program for potential future 
financing of assets and development of performance management indicators; (iii) a program to 
develop capacity in asset management; and (iv) proposals for establishing mechanisms to 
finance the management of road assets sustainably. ADB has helped other governments in 
Southeast Asia to improve the management of their road assets, e.g., Cambodia.6 Lessons 
learned from this experience will be incorporated in the TA. 
 
10.  Activities will include (i) preparing a detailed inventory of the road assets under MOC’s 
control, including their condition; (ii) determining through this analysis the parts of the network 
that are suitable for periodic and routine maintenance programs, and those that will require 
complete  rehabilitation; (iii)  analyzing  MOC’s  existing  asset  management  and  maintenance 
operations;  (iv)  establishing  an  asset  management  database  and  information  system; 
(v)  developing an assessment and evaluation mechanism for prioritizing road maintenance 
under a range of defined road condition requirements and budget options; (vi) preparing and 
                                                
5  ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance to the Republic of the Union of Myanmar: Capacity Development and Institutional 
Support. Manila; ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance to the Republic of the Union of Myanmar: Capacity Building 
Support for Project Identification. Manila. 
6  ADB. 2008. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to the 
Kingdom of Cambodia for the Road Asset Management Project. Manila.

3 
costing annual maintenance programs for the identified priority network sections over an initial 
5-year period; (vii) undertaking a needs assessment of MOC staff’s asset management capacity; 
(viii) preparing and delivering a capacity development program for the relevant MOC and Public 
Works staff, and (ix) proposing a range of approaches for funding the asset management 
program  on  a  sustainable  basis. These  proposed  approaches  could  include  private  sector 
concessions  and  a  dedicated  road  fund  supported  by  a  fuel  or  other  transport-related 
surcharges. The TA will review the experiences in raising such funding in other ADB developing 
member countries, as well as in nations in Africa and South America. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,365,000 which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, field survey teams for asset inventories and 
road asset condition surveys, office accommodation and supplies, venues for workshops and 
seminars,  and  other  in-kind  contributions.  The  cost  estimates  and  financing  plan  are  in 
Appendix 2. Disbursements under the TA will follow ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  The MOC will be the executing agency and Public Works will be the implementing 
agency. ADB will be responsible for recruiting consultants and managing their contracts. 
 
13.  The TA will be implemented during the 20 months from April 2013 to November 2014. It 
will include consultancy services to be provided by an engineering firm or one with similar 
qualifications.  International  consultants  (31  person-months)  and  national  consultants  (28 
person-months) will be engaged on a full-time or intermittent basis to work with MOC and Public 
Works staff assigned to the TA. An outline terms of reference for the consultants is in Appendix 
3. Consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will use the quality- and cost-based 
method  of  selection.  It  will  employ  a  quality:cost  ratio  of  90:10  to  address  the  need  for 
exceptionally high-quality consultants that the complex project  will present. A full technical 
proposal  will  be  used  in  selecting  the  consulting  firm.  Consultants  will  manage  surveys, 
workshops, training, seminars, and conferences under the TA budget. Equipment procurement 
will comply with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). The 
assets will be handed over to the  executing and/or implementing agency when the TA is 
completed. 
 
14.  Implementation will be monitored through monthly progress reports, as well as through 
the standard reporting requirements for (i) an inception report (at the end of May 2013); (ii) an 
interim report (at the end of March 2014); (iii) a draft final report (at the end of September 2014); 
and (iv) a final report (at the end of November 2014). The TA consultants will also provide 
reports on (i) the inventory and condition analysis of road assets in the form of a database, 
along  with  associated  software  and  manuals;  (ii)  a  mechanism  for  road  maintenance 
prioritization in the form of a toolkit, together with associated indicative investment programs for 
future  financing;  (iii)  a  capacity  development  program  and  training  material  for  capacity 
development in road asset management; and (iv) future investment and financial requirements 
and  suitable  sources  of  sustainable  finance.  The  TA  will  include  workshops  and  training 
seminars for the capacity development in road asset management.

4   
15.  Findings and reports from the TA will be disseminated through the ADB website. The 
work will also be showcased at national and relevant events in Asia. 
 
16.  The government will ensure the availability of (i) all relevant documents, data, and any 
other information that may be required by the TA consultants to meet the objectives of the TA; 
(ii) the appropriate qualified counterpart staff, and secretarial and clerical support; (iii) suitable 
office accommodation and equipment; and (iv) logistical assistance to prepare venues, identify 
and  invite  participants,  provide  secretarial  services,  and  manage  coordination  for  the  TA 
workshops and seminars. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,365,000  to  the 
Government of Myanmar to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for  Poverty 
Reduction for the Developing the Asset Management Program for Myanmar Roads, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Team Composition 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require the following consultants: 
 
2.  Highway engineer and team leader (international, 18 person-months). The engineer 
should have at least 15 years of relevant experience in areas relating to planning, operations, 
and performance evaluation in road asset management. At least 10 years of this experience 
should be international experience, preferably in developing economies. ADB prefers that the 
engineer has a master’s degree or the equivalent in transport-related areas. The engineer will 
act as team leader and will provide both the technical expertise and the project management 
and supervisory skills required to manage a team of international and national experts. As team 
leader, the engineer will (i) have overall responsibility for all the work conducted and the reports 
prepared; (ii) work closely with national and international specialists to ensure the quality of the 
work produced; and (iii) act as the chief liaison for the consulting team with the government and 
with the Asian Development Bank (ADB). Specific tasks will include: 
(i)  preparing a detailed inventory of existing Ministry of Construction (MOC) road 
assets; 
(ii)  preparing an analysis of the condition of MOC road assets; 
(iii)  preparing periodic and routine maintenance programs; 
(iv)  reporting  on  and  providing  an  assessment  of  operational  procedures  in  the 
national road subsector under MOC management; 
(v)  establishing an asset management database and information system; 
(vi)  preparing,  with  the  transport  economist,  an  evaluation  mechanism  for  road 
maintenance prioritization; 
(vii)  prepare  an  investment  program,  with  cost  estimates,  for  future  road  asset 
improvements and investment; 
(viii)  assisting the capacity development specialist in capacity needs assessment and 
in the design and pilot testing of a capacity development training program for 
asset management; and 
(ix)  assisting the financial specialist in the assessment and development of suitable 
financing  mechanisms  for  asset  management  and  in  identifying  sustainable 
financial resources for asset management. 
 
3.  Transport economist (international, 5 person-months). The economist should have at 
least  10  years  of  relevant  experience  in  areas  relating  to  road  assessment  and  asset 
management. At least 5 years of this experience which should be appropriate international 
experience, preferably in developing economies. ADB prefers that the economist has a master’s 
degree or the equivalent in transport economics or related fields. Specific tasks will include 
(i)  preparing  an  assessment  and  evaluation  mechanism  for  prioritizing  road 
maintenance; 
(ii)  preparing  an  investment  program  for  future  road  asset  improvements  and 
investment; 
(iii)  working  with  the  highway  engineer  to  develop  a  performance  management 
system for improved operational efficiencies; and 
(iv)  providing inputs on economic aspects of the project and road asset management, 
as required. 
 
4.  Capacity development and training specialist (international, 5 person-months). The 
specialist should have at least 10 years of relevant experience in areas relating to capacity

Appendix 3  9 
development  and  delivery  of  training  programs  to  government  institutions  or  similar  large 
organizations in the private sector (preferably in the transport sector). At least 5 years of this 
experience should be appropriate international experience, preferably in developing economies. 
ADB prefers that the specialist has a master’s or an equivalent degree in capacity development 
and training. Specific tasks will include 
(i)  undertaking  a  needs  assessment  of  government  staff  capacity  in  asset 
management and project investment; 
(ii)  preparing and delivering a capacity development and training program for asset 
management; 
(iii)  assisting  the  project  team  with  stakeholder  participation,  outreach,  and 
workshops, as required; and 
(iv)  preparing  the  communication  plan  and  related  materials  for  the  asset 
management capacity development program. 
 
5.  Financial  specialist (international, 3 person-months). The specialist should have at 
least 10 years of relevant experience in areas relating to financial evaluation and performance 
monitoring  of  infrastructure  (preferably  in  the  transport  sector).  At  least  5  years  of  this 
experience should be appropriate international experience, preferably in developing economies. 
ADB prefers that the specialist has a master’s or an equivalent degree in finance or transport-
related fields. Specific tasks will include 
(i)  preparing  future  annual  road  maintenance  requirements  from  a  financial 
perspective; 
(ii)  developing suitable financing mechanisms and revenue sources for sustainable 
financial viability of road asset management; 
(iii)  exploring potential for private sector involvement in potential financial modalities 
for asset management; and 
(iv)  providing any inputs that may be required on financial aspects of the project and 
road asset management.  
 
6.  Highway  engineer  (national,  18  person-months).  The  engineer  should  hold  an 
engineering  degree  or the  equivalent,  with  at  least  10  years  of  relevant  work  experience, 
preferably with international organizations. The engineer will assist the international highway 
engineer with the tasks outlined in para. 2. The national engineer will act as the deputy team 
leader and liaise with government counterpart staff during implementation of the TA. 
 
7.  Capacity  development  and  training  specialist  (national,  10  person-months).  The 
specialist should hold a bachelor’s (or higher) degree in a related field and have demonstrated 
experience in the development and delivery of capacity development training, preferably to 
government and/or other public sector institutions. The specialist should have at least 10 years 
of relevant work experience, preferably with international organizations. The specialist will assist 
the international capacity development and training specialist in the tasks outlined in para. 4. 
The national specialist will support the team leader and other team members in all aspects 
related  to  capacity  development  training  during  TA  implementation.  The  specialist  will  be 
responsible  for  the  piloting  and  delivery  of  the  capacity  development  training  program  to 
government officials and civil society and private sector groups. 
 
B.  Reporting Requirements 
 
8.  The TA will produce both project and specific reports. Project reports will include the 
following standard monitoring reports: (i) an inception report (at the end of May 2013); (ii) an 
interim report (at the end of March 2014); (iii) a draft final report (at the end of September 2014);

10  Appendix 3 
and (iv) a final report (at the end of November 2014). The specific reports will cover key areas of 
the TA, including (i) an inventory and condition analysis of road assets in the form of a database, 
with associated software and manuals; (ii) a mechanism for road maintenance prioritization in 
the form of a toolkit and associated indicative investment programs for future financing; (iii) a 
capacity development program and training material for capacity development in road asset 
management; and (iv) future investment and financial requirements, including suitable sources 
of sustainable finance. The TA will include workshops and training seminars to support the 
capacity development and training in road asset management. 
 
9.  Findings and reports from the TA will be disseminated through the ADB website. The 
work will also be showcased at national and regional events. 
 
10.  All deliverables and reports listed in these terms of reference will be submitted to ADB 
on schedule in digital computer format prepared with Microsoft Word software. Six hard copies 
of the deliverables will also be provided, two each for ADB, MOC, and Public Works. Final 
reports must be delivered on a compact disk, along with the specified number of hard copies.
